trans-unit.source: Activity: Binary transmogrifier
trans-unit.target: Activity: バイナリー transmogrifier

trans-unit.source: Guide the students through building a binary transmogrifier (converter) that converts between binary (base-2) and decimal (base-10) numbers.
trans-unit.target: Guide the students through building a binary transmogrifier (converter) that converts between binary (base-2) and decimal (base-10) numbers.

trans-unit.source: Let them figure out a pattern that will allow them to do the conversion on the fly.
trans-unit.target: Let them figure out a pattern that will allow them to do the conversion on the fly.

trans-unit.source: /static/courses/csintro/binary/transmogrifier.png
trans-unit.target: /static/courses/csintro/binary/transmogrifier.png

trans-unit.source: Transmogrifier cartoon
trans-unit.target: Transmogrifier cartoon

trans-unit.source: Calvin & Hobbes
trans-unit.target: Calvin & Hobbes

trans-unit.source: Tell the students that they will be building a binary transmogrifier with the micro:bit.
trans-unit.target: Tell the students that they will be building a binary transmogrifier with the micro:bit.

trans-unit.source: The user will be able to use the buttons to enter binary 0s and 1s and will be able to press A+B at any time to display the decimal equivalent of the number that has been entered.
trans-unit.target: The user will be able to use the buttons to enter binary 0s and 1s and will be able to press A+B at any time to display the decimal equivalent of the number that has been entered.

trans-unit.source: Create the Variables
trans-unit.target: Create the Variables

trans-unit.source: Students will need to create a number variable to hold the running decimal total. They should also create a string variable to hold the current binary number.
trans-unit.target: Students will need to create a number variable to hold the running decimal total. They should also create a string variable to hold the current binary number.

trans-unit.source: From the Variables menu, make and name these two variables: decimal, binary.
trans-unit.target: From the Variables menu, make and name these two variables: decimal, binary.

trans-unit.source: /static/courses/csintro/binary/make-a-variable.png
trans-unit.target: /static/courses/csintro/binary/make-a-variable.png

trans-unit.source: Make a variable
trans-unit.target: Make a variable
trans-unit.note: Context: Image Alternative Text XPath: /blockquote/p/img[@alt] Screenshot: https://crowdin.com/s/wrap/73e383g3m4d3v6b38307u4p4o45555p4q455m2i463530565c6?t=64843

trans-unit.source: /static/courses/csintro/binary/name-a-variable.png
trans-unit.target: /static/courses/csintro/binary/name-a-variable.png

trans-unit.source: Name a variable
trans-unit.target: Name a variable

trans-unit.source: Initialize the Variables
trans-unit.target: Initialize the Variables

trans-unit.source: When the program starts up, you should initialize your variables to starting values.
trans-unit.target: When the program starts up, you should initialize your variables to starting values.

trans-unit.source: decimal = 0
trans-unit.target: decimal = 0

trans-unit.source: binary = "" (empty string) This also tells the micro:bit what type of variable it is.
trans-unit.target: binary = "" (empty string) This also tells the micro:bit what type of variable it is.

trans-unit.source: Use the empty string value found in the Text toolbox drawer, under the Advanced menu.
trans-unit.target: Use the empty string value found in the Text toolbox drawer, under the Advanced menu.

trans-unit.source: /static/courses/csintro/binary/select-text-blocks.png
trans-unit.target: /static/courses/csintro/binary/select-text-blocks.png

trans-unit.source: Select text on block menu
trans-unit.target: Select text on block menu

trans-unit.source: let binary = "" let decimal = 0
trans-unit.target: let binary = "" let decimal = 0

trans-unit.source: By setting the binary variable to an initial value of “ “ you tell the micro:bit that it is a string variable: a literal string of characters.
trans-unit.target: By setting the binary variable to an initial value of “ “ you tell the micro:bit that it is a string variable: a literal string of characters.

trans-unit.source: This is important because you will be adding to this string character by character.
trans-unit.target: This is important because you will be adding to this string character by character.

trans-unit.source: Transmogrify Me!
trans-unit.target: Transmogrify Me!

trans-unit.source: We are ready to start entering numbers.
trans-unit.target: We are ready to start entering numbers.

trans-unit.source: Remember that binary numbers are calculated based on the number of place values (“bits”) and as you enter 1s and 0s, the value changes.
trans-unit.target: Remember that binary numbers are calculated based on the number of place values (“bits”) and as you enter 1s and 0s, the value changes.

trans-unit.source: One way to calculate the decimal value is to wait until the user presses A+B, and then calculate the entire number based on the value of the string.
trans-unit.target: One way to calculate the decimal value is to wait until the user presses A+B, and then calculate the entire number based on the value of the string.

trans-unit.source: However, a much simpler method is to calculate the decimal number “on the fly”, which is to say, every time the user presses a 1 or a 0, calculate the current decimal value of that string so you only have to deal with one 0 or 1 at a time.
trans-unit.target: However, a much simpler method is to calculate the decimal number “on the fly”, which is to say, every time the user presses a 1 or a 0, calculate the current decimal value of that string so you only have to deal with one 0 or 1 at a time.

trans-unit.source: What’s the Pattern?
trans-unit.target: What’s the Pattern?

trans-unit.source: This is a table of the first fourteen binary numbers and their decimal equivalents.
trans-unit.target: This is a table of the first fourteen binary numbers and their decimal equivalents.

trans-unit.source: Your goal is to use this table to figure out how to calculate a new correct decimal value based on whether a user enters a 0, or a 1 as the next number in the string.
trans-unit.target: Your goal is to use this table to figure out how to calculate a new correct decimal value based on whether a user enters a 0, or a 1 as the next number in the string.

trans-unit.source: For example, imagine you are the micro:bit.
trans-unit.target: For example, imagine you are the micro:bit.

trans-unit.source: If the first number the human enters is a 1, you automatically know the new decimal value is a 1.
trans-unit.target: If the first number the human enters is a 1, you automatically know the new decimal value is a 1.

trans-unit.source: If the second number that is entered is a 0, then your decimal value goes from 1 to 2.
trans-unit.target: If the second number that is entered is a 0, then your decimal value goes from 1 to 2.

trans-unit.source: However, if the second number is also a 1, then your new decimal value goes from 1 to 3.
trans-unit.target: However, if the second number is also a 1, then your new decimal value goes from 1 to 3.

trans-unit.source: At that point, you either have a 10, or a 11 in your binary string.
trans-unit.target: At that point, you either have a 10, or a 11 in your binary string.

trans-unit.source: Let’s take 10 as an example.
trans-unit.target: Let’s take 10 as an example.

trans-unit.source: The decimal value of binary 10 is 2.
trans-unit.target: The decimal value of binary 10 is 2.

trans-unit.source: If the third number entered is a 0, then your new decimal value goes from 2 to 4.
trans-unit.target: If the third number entered is a 0, then your new decimal value goes from 2 to 4.

trans-unit.source: If the third number entered is a 1, then your new decimal value goes from 2 to 5.
trans-unit.target: If the third number entered is a 1, then your new decimal value goes from 2 to 5.

trans-unit.source: If, on the other hand, you have 11 in your binary string, then your decimal value is 3.
trans-unit.target: If, on the other hand, you have 11 in your binary string, then your decimal value is 3.

trans-unit.source: If the third number entered is a 0, then your new decimal value goes from 3 to 6.
trans-unit.target: If the third number entered is a 0, then your new decimal value goes from 3 to 6.

trans-unit.source: If the third number entered is a 1, then your new decimal value goes from 3 to 7.
trans-unit.target: If the third number entered is a 1, then your new decimal value goes from 3 to 7.

trans-unit.source: See if you can spot a pattern that will help you figure out, for any given decimal value, what the new decimal value should be if the user enters a 0, or if the user enters a 1.
trans-unit.target: See if you can spot a pattern that will help you figure out, for any given decimal value, what the new decimal value should be if the user enters a 0, or if the user enters a 1.

trans-unit.source: /static/courses/csintro/binary/binary-patterns.png
trans-unit.target: /static/courses/csintro/binary/binary-patterns.png

trans-unit.source: Binary number patterns
trans-unit.target: Binary number patterns

trans-unit.source: Pseudocode
trans-unit.target: 擬似コード

trans-unit.source: Recall from our Algorithms lesson that it is a good idea to write out your algorithm in plain English, before you start coding in MakeCode.
trans-unit.target: Recall from our Algorithms lesson that it is a good idea to write out your algorithm in plain English, before you start coding in MakeCode.

trans-unit.source: This is called pseudocode.
trans-unit.target: This is called pseudocode.

trans-unit.source: The Input for this program will be the buttons.
trans-unit.target: The Input for this program will be the buttons.

trans-unit.source: Try to write out what should happen when each of the buttons is pressed.
trans-unit.target: Try to write out what should happen when each of the buttons is pressed.

trans-unit.source: Here is one possible solution. Your own pseudocode might be different and that’s okay.
trans-unit.target: Here is one possible solution. Your own pseudocode might be different and that’s okay.

trans-unit.source: When Button A is pressed:
trans-unit.target: When Button A is pressed:

trans-unit.source: Add a “1” to the end of the binary string.
trans-unit.target: Add a “1” to the end of the binary string.

trans-unit.source: Show the current value of the binary string.
trans-unit.target: Show the current value of the binary string.

trans-unit.source: Update the decimal value with the total.
trans-unit.target: Update the decimal value with the total.

trans-unit.source: When Button B is pressed:
trans-unit.target: When Button B is pressed:

trans-unit.source: Add a “0” to the end of the binary string.
trans-unit.target: Add a “0” to the end of the binary string.

trans-unit.source: Show the current value of the binary string.
trans-unit.target: Show the current value of the binary string.

trans-unit.source: Update the decimal value with the total.
trans-unit.target: Update the decimal value with the total.

trans-unit.source: When Buttons A+B are pressed:
trans-unit.target: When Buttons A+B are pressed:

trans-unit.source: Show the current value of the decimal string.
trans-unit.target: Show the current value of the decimal string.

trans-unit.source: Coding Steps
trans-unit.target: Coding Steps

trans-unit.source: From the Input Toolbox drawer, drag 3 of the ‘on button A pressed’ event handlers to your coding workspace
trans-unit.target: From the Input Toolbox drawer, drag 3 of the ‘on button A pressed’ event handlers to your coding workspace

trans-unit.source: Leave one block with button 'A’. Use the drop-down menus in the other 2 blocks to choose button ‘B’, and button ‘A+B’
trans-unit.target: Leave one block with button 'A’. Use the drop-down menus in the other 2 blocks to choose button ‘B’, and button ‘A+B’

trans-unit.source: Let’s work on what to do when button A is pressed.
trans-unit.target: Let’s work on what to do when button A is pressed.

trans-unit.source: Button A represents a binary “1”. Our first task is to join a “1” to the existing string variable called binary.
trans-unit.target: Button A represents a binary “1”. Our first task is to join a “1” to the existing string variable called binary.

trans-unit.source: From the Text Toolbox drawer (under the Advanced menu), drag the 'join' block to your programming workspace
trans-unit.target: From the Text Toolbox drawer (under the Advanced menu), drag the 'join' block to your programming workspace

trans-unit.source: Next, use the 'set' variable block to assign the value of the 'binary' variable to the 'join' block
trans-unit.target: Next, use the 'set' variable block to assign the value of the 'binary' variable to the 'join' block

trans-unit.source: Join the 'binary' variable and “1” by entering them into the appropriate slots in the 'join' block
trans-unit.target: Join the 'binary' variable and “1” by entering them into the appropriate slots in the 'join' block

trans-unit.source: And show the binary value on the screen so that when users press a button they can see the entire binary string
trans-unit.target: And show the binary value on the screen so that when users press a button they can see the entire binary string

trans-unit.source: Finally, you will need to update the current decimal value with the value of the entire binary string.
trans-unit.target: Finally, you will need to update the current decimal value with the value of the entire binary string.

trans-unit.source: This is pretty straightforward if you have been keeping track of the decimal value every time someone presses a button.
trans-unit.target: This is pretty straightforward if you have been keeping track of the decimal value every time someone presses a button.

trans-unit.source: The pattern is as follows: (spoiler alert!)
trans-unit.target: The pattern is as follows: (spoiler alert!)

trans-unit.source: Whenever someone enters a 0, the new decimal value is twice the previous value.
trans-unit.target: Whenever someone enters a 0, the new decimal value is twice the previous value.

trans-unit.source: If someone enters a 1, the new decimal value is twice the previous value, plus 1.
trans-unit.target: If someone enters a 1, the new decimal value is twice the previous value, plus 1.

trans-unit.source: For Button A, you will need to use the multiplication Math block and your binary variable block to create the proper formula.
trans-unit.target: For Button A, you will need to use the multiplication Math block and your binary variable block to create the proper formula.

trans-unit.source: You will need to put that formula inside another Math addition block in order to add one to the result.
trans-unit.target: You will need to put that formula inside another Math addition block in order to add one to the result.

trans-unit.source: let binary = "" let decimal = 0 input.onButtonPressed(Button.A, () => { binary = binary + "1" basic.showString(binary) decimal = decimal * 2 + 1 })
trans-unit.target: let binary = "" let decimal = 0 input.onButtonPressed(Button.A, () => { binary = binary + "1" basic.showString(binary) decimal = decimal * 2 + 1 })

trans-unit.source: Your Button B algorithm is similar, although you will be joining a “0” to the binary variable and you are just multiplying the decimal variable by 2.
trans-unit.target: Your Button B algorithm is similar, although you will be joining a “0” to the binary variable and you are just multiplying the decimal variable by 2.

trans-unit.source: Your Button A+B algorithm just uses a Show block to show the value of the decimal variable.
trans-unit.target: Your Button A+B algorithm just uses a Show block to show the value of the decimal variable.

trans-unit.source: Here is the completed program.
trans-unit.target: Here is the completed program.

trans-unit.source: Try it out!
trans-unit.target: Try it out!

trans-unit.source: Have someone else try your program out. Then think about how the program might be improved. Here are some additional modifications you might try:
trans-unit.target: Have someone else try your program out. Then think about how the program might be improved. Here are some additional modifications you might try:

trans-unit.source: Add a way to clear the binary and decimal values so you can start over.
trans-unit.target: Add a way to clear the binary and decimal values so you can start over.

trans-unit.source: Add a way to erase the previous value.
trans-unit.target: Add a way to erase the previous value.

trans-unit.source: Create a decimal-binary converter that allows you enter a decimal value and see the binary equivalent when you press A+B.
trans-unit.target: Create a decimal-binary converter that allows you enter a decimal value and see the binary equivalent when you press A+B.
